Subject: Back at it for spring semester!
Text:
Happy Sunday everyone!

Wanted to take a moment to outline how things are going to look the next couple weeks 
while the semester gets underway with online classes. This info will be cross-posted in 
email & in Teams.

In the hope of reducing the risk of spreading the omicron variant through support center 
staff, we are reducing the number of people who will be working in person in Carnegie. 
As such:
1.	I will be working remotely for several weeks (end date not yet determined).
2.	There will be two ITCR leaders in Carnegie each day, rotating between Jerome, 
Clayton, and Greg.
3.	There will be two campus techs on duty in Carnegie each day on a rotating 
schedule; all others will be working remotely.
4.	We’ll have one imaging student working at a time in room 7.
5.	For all other student techs, we’ll have one working at the front desk in Carn; other 
students scheduled will be working either remotely or at the not-lead desk in the 
big room.
a.	The remote student should use the student2 account.
b.	The front desk phones should be logged into student5 & student6 – I 
expect student6 should be set to “do not disturb” most of the time.
c.	The classroom emergency phone should be logged into student4.
d.	The not-lead desk student/second remote student should use the student3 
account.
6.	Masks must be propertly worn at all times in Carnegie. You may only remove 
it to drink a beverage or eat something; you must be seated/stationary when 
doing so. (In other words, no walking around drinking from your water bottle.) 
Your mask must cover from above your nose to below your chin.
a.	I strongly recommend you wear an N95/KN95 mask or similar, until we’re 
past the omicron peak. If you need one, let me know. They can be safely 
reused by following some simple steps.
7.	There will be an all staff meeting scheduled in the very near future – please stay 
tuned for that info.
8.	From a support perspective, students may still walk-in to request assistance in 
the support center.
9.	Faculty/staff must have an appointment; these appointments are generated by 
campus techs after attempting remote support first. In other words: a faculty/staff 
member should not ask you to set an appointment on behalf of a campus tech. 
Make sure there’s a ticket entered and advise the user that the tech will set up 
the time with them.
10.	If you are feeling unwell for any reason, do not come to work. We don’t want 
germs spreading around, and this is NOT a case of “sharing is caring.” ??
a.	If you test positive at any time, please notify me ASAP in addition to 
notifying contacttracing@drake.edu.
11.	Remember to always include Allison and Sam in any communications where 
you’d normally contact me, especially in regard to scheduling related requests.

There’s a lot that’s changed lately, so I expect there will be a lot of confusion from our 
returning users. Here’s a short list:
1.	Microsoft MFA went live at the beginning of the month, replacing Duo.
2.	We have new/different tools for managing MFA settings for users that are part of 
Password Manager.
3.	myDrake and other services now require the use of MFA.
4.	MyDUSIS no longer exists and has been replaced by a tool called Self Service.
5.	A number of changes have been made to TeamDynamix services as they relate 
to Banner, myDrake, Self Service, etc – make sure you review the portal to 
familiarize yourself.
6.	Parent access to student information is changing, and ITS will NOT be able to fix 
their login issues; they will have to contact their student to fix access.

That’s the “quick” overview. Yes, I know it’s a lot. And yes, that means there’s more we 
haven’t yet covered.

As always, if you have questions, just ask! I’m available on Teams to chat anytime you 
need it.
-Becky


-- 
Becky Klein, M.A. (she/her/hers)
Assistant Director – Campus Relations, Information Technology Services 
Adjunct Professor, Bulldog Foundations
Advisor, Sigma Alpha Iota, Pi chapter
Drake University

Subject: South African J-term (2022)
Text:
Hi all, 

If you are receiving this email, then you have expressed interest in the J22 travel seminar to South Africa 
(and Zimbabwe). 

I am Prof. Knepper, one of the professors for the class. The other professor, Herbert Moyo, is a 
Zimbabwean who teaches in South Africa. He will be with us for the entire trip and will also accompany 
us back to Drake, where he will serve as the S22 “Global Scholar in Residence.” 

The travel seminar will visit the cities of Johannesburg, Durban, and Pietermaritzburg in South Africa, as 
well as Bulawayo in Zimbabwe. (We will also spend much time in the countryside.) The focus of the trip 
is lived religion, which includes African Christianity, European/missionary Christianity, indigenous 
religion (especially sangoma practice), Islam, and Hinduism. We will visit many different places of 
worship. We will also spend some time working with students from University of KwaZulu-Natal (where 
Herbert teaches) on a photo-narrative project about lived religion. 

On Tuesday of next week (3/30), I will hold an informational session from 4-5 pm. Feel free to drop in 
any time to ask questions. Here is the link: https://drake-edu.zoom.us/j/82477311829.

Also, you may of course simply email questions to me. 

All best, 
Tim

-----
Timothy D Knepper
Professor of Philosophy, Drake University

Greetings Members of the Drake Community,

Today marks the start of Black History Month. We center and celebrate the empowerment, 
achievement, and contributions of African American communities, not only as they manifest in the 
present and come to us through the past—but in terms of the hope they hold for our collective future. 

History matters. 

The origins of Black History month go back to the leadership of intellectual giant, Dr. Carter G. Woodson. 
Woodson established the Association for the Study of African American Life and History (ASALH) in 1915 
after participating in a national event to commemorate the 50th anniversary of emancipation. Dr. 
Woodson worked tirelessly throughout his life to promote widespread knowledge of Black history. He 
knew the past and future are connected, declaring the vision this way, “We are going back to that 
beautiful history and it is going to inspire us to greater achievements.”

In February 1926, Woodson’s ASALH sponsored the first week-long celebration of Black history. This was 
timing they chose, in part, because the great Frederick Douglass was born on February 12. Within 20 
years, Black communities all over the country turned a week into a month and then, in 1976, the first 
official presidential declaration of February as Black History Month was conferred. This declaration has 
been made every year since. 

It’s vital we all continue to learn about, lift up, and honor the endless contributions of African Americans 
to every aspect of U.S.-American life. Black history is U.S.-American history. 

It’s also important we insist on our rights and responsibilities to do just that! As political pressures are 
mounting all over the country—including in the state of Iowa—to limit how fully and honestly we talk 
about U.S. racial history in public life, we need to deepen our knowledge of African American life, joy, 
wisdom, sacrifice and struggle to be honored as full citizens and human beings.  We need to understand 
the ways history continues to resonate in the present. Just today a dozen Historically Black Colleges and 
University’s (HBCUs) received bomb threads. Black lives and well-being matter. 

It's also a joy to celebrate Black History and recognize the many African American people who are the 
Drake community, who make Des Moines what it is, who are Iowa. Black creativity, brilliance, and 
commitment are boundless. 

I want to encourage you to participate in the countless opportunities for celebration and 
acknowledgement that will be offered to all of us this month. 

Read about members of the Drake community in a story series called Voices of Drake. The first story in 
the series highlights Jazlin Coley–Smith, Director for Equity and Inclusion. Show up to one of the many 
events sponsored by the Coalition of Black Students. Learn about the Black suffragette’s courage to 
secure the vote. Spend an evening with Ty Marcellus (NuWorld Comics) who is creating a universe to 
rival Marvel’s. Join Dr. Brandi Brimmer to hear about southern Black women’s journey to secure 
freedom for themselves after the Civil War and what these legacies mean for us today. 

There is so much to learn, celebrate, and continue to share.

Finally, in appreciation of Black History month, an offering of poetry, shared by Provost Sue Mattison. 
This poem was written by Clint Smith who is an award-winning poet, writer for the Atlantic and author 
of New York Times bestseller How the Word Is Passed. 

Meteor Shower
by Clint Smith

I read somewhere that meteor showers
are almost always named after

the constellations from which
they originate. It’s funny, I think,

how even the universe is telling us
that we can never get too far

from the place that created us.
How there is always a streak of our past

trailing closely behind us
like a smattering of obstinate memories.

Even when we enter a new atmosphere,
become subsumed in flames, turn to dust,

lose ourselves in the wind, and scatter
the surface of all that rests beneath us,

we bring a part of where we are from 
to every place we go.


__________________________________
 
Jennifer Harvey, PhD (she/her/hers)
Associate Provost of Campus Equity and Inclusion
Drake University

T  515-271-2885
E  jennifer.harvey@drake.edu
W  https://www.drake.edu/diversity  
 
 

***** 
i want to live in a world where harm
is not systemic, where love organizes
society, where the earth is respected,
and where life is valued above all else

-yung pueblo

Subject: COVID-19 Drake Update - September 17, 2021
Text:
The Drake University Emergency Operations Center sends operational updates to all faculty, 
staff, and students. President Martin and Provost Mattison will share additional messages, as 
appropriate. Please read the entirety of each message.

September 17, 2021

Key Points (as of this morning)
*	There are five students with confirmed cases of COVID-19 in on-campus isolation
*	There are 15 students with confirmed cases of COVID-19 off campus
*	There are 15 students in quarantine
*	79.8% of employees are fully vaccinated
*	70% of all registered students, 76% of students with at least one class in person, and 
86% of residential students have submitted their vaccination record
*	Securely report your vaccination to Drake
Upcoming OSHA COVID-19 Mitigation Requirements 
The Department of Labor’s Occupational Safety and Health Administration (OSHA) is developing 
a rule that will require all employers with 100 or more employees to ensure their workforce is 
fully vaccinated or require any workers who remain unvaccinated to produce a negative test 
result on at least a weekly basis. OSHA will issue an Emergency Temporary Standard (ETS) to 
implement this requirement in the coming weeks. Once that ETS is issued, more will be known 
about the timeline for implementation and the specific requirements of the standard. 

Faculty, staff, and student employees who have not yet been vaccinated or submitted proof of 
vaccination are strongly encouraged to do so now so that the University is well positioned to 
comply with this new requirement once it takes effect. Any changes to Drake policies or 
protocols will be communicated to campus in a variety of ways, including through COVID-19 
Updates. Faculty, staff, and student employees should submit documentation using this secure, 
mobile friendly, and easy to use form. 

Drake Testing Options 
Students experiencing COVID-19 symptoms can be tested at no cost at the Student Health 
Center. Students should call 515-271-3731 before showing up in person. 

Drake administers PCR tests, which are the most accurate type of COVID-19 test. Due to the 
higher risk of producing a false negative result with an antigen test, the University strongly 
recommends obtaining a PCR test from the Student Health Center or seeking out a test site that 
administers PCR tests.

Faculty and staff experiencing COVID-19 symptoms must contact Chris Nickell, director of 
environmental health and safety, at chris.nickell@drake.edu to receive instructions on how to 
obtain a test at no charge from the University.

For more information about COVID-19 testing at Drake, please see the COVID-19 Testing FAQ.

Fall Break Status 
At this time, Fall Break remains scheduled for October 18 and 19. Given the rapidly changing 
impacts of the Delta COVID-19 variant on our community, Provost Mattison may move Fall 
Break to November 22 and 23 (Thanksgiving week) at her discretion, with Faculty Senate having 
consented to this potential change (Motion 22-01, August 5, 2021).

Student Vaccine Incentives Update 
Should Drake reach 80% of students with at least one class on campus reporting full vaccination 
by Sept. 24, 20 students will be awarded one-time (non-renewable) scholarships in the amount 
of $2,500. Currently 76% of students with at least one class on campus have submitted proof of 
vaccination to the University. Additional details can be found in this Aug. 6 message. 

Securely Report Your Vaccine
Submitting proof of your vaccination is highly encouraged so the University can make 
accurate and informed decisions about safe campus operations. Students, faculty, and staff 
should submit documentation using this secure, mobile friendly, and easy to use form. 

Face Coverings 
The University Face Coverings Policy remains in effect. Even if you believe everyone is 
vaccinated, this policy applies and will be enforced. It is important that we all consistently 
adhere to this policy to ensure we are protecting both ourselves and others within the campus 
community.

COVID-19 Symptoms
Please re-familiarize yourself with the CDC’s list of common COVID-19 symptoms. It is possible 
for fully vaccinated individuals to contract and spread COVID-19, so please be aware of changes 
in your health no matter your vaccination status.

Do Your Part 
It is up to each one of us to protect ourselves and each other. Employees and students living off 
campus who do not feel well must avoid coming to campus until they are healthy. Please 
continue to follow the University’s safety protocols: wear a mask and remember to wash your 
hands properly and often. By doing your best to avoid exposure to the coronavirus, you are 
helping save lives and medical resources for those who need them most. 

Minimizing the risk of COVID-19 infections is a shared responsibility. Drake’s plans are aligned 
and consistent with local and state guidance. The University follows recommendations from the 
Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC), Iowa Department of Public Health, and Polk 
County health officials.

Please visit drake.edu/coronavirus, which houses a repository of campus updates and messages 
pertaining to the COVID-19 pandemic and provides answers to many frequently asked 
questions.

Good Afternoon,

I hope you have a safe and fun St. Patties Day! I’m reaching out to see what your plans are for after graduation. Have your original plans changed? I wanted to provide an opportunity that you may not know about, pathway to becoming a leader of Marines!  As a college graduate, you can use your degree to become an officer in the United States Marine Corps.  Officers are leaders that use their education and experiences to train, develop, coach and mentor young Marines.


Do you like physical fitness, complex problem-solving, leadership, and decision making?


Do you seek to serve a purpose greater than yourself?

What do you know about Marine Corps Officer Commissioning Programs?

Marine Corps Officers are four-year college graduates who serve in leadership roles and can specialize in nearly any occupation available outside of the Marine Corps.  Officers are employed in management roles, typically providing guidance and oversight to enlisted Marines.

Officers have higher levels of responsibility than enlisted members, and also receive higher pay.  Starting salaries for full-time officers are typically around $55,000-$70,000 with increases tied to promotions.  This pay includes full medical, dental, life insurance.
